text: Ok, I believe in August we updated the wrappers for the Gtk3_jll stack, to get a small speedup in the loading time of Gtk.jl. In October we finally moved to JLLWrappers (only 10 months after its creation). The mass update in October helped me with Hacktoberfest :joy:

elements.text: Ok, I believe in August we updated the wrappers for the Gtk3_jll stack, to get a small speedup in the loading time of Gtk.jl. In October we finally moved to JLLWrappers (only 10 months after its creation). The mass update in October helped me with Hacktoberfest

text:
JLLWrappers has been a massive quality-of-life improvement for us in terms of maintainance and efficiency: JLL packages now share a lot of code, drastically reducing compilation (see <https://github.com/JuliaGraphics/Gtk.jl/issues/466#issuecomment-716058685|https://github.com/JuliaGraphics/Gtk.jl/issues/466#issuecomment-716058685> for the speedup in Gtk3_jll), and we can push fixes to all packages just by fixing JLLWrappers (we already did this once or twice), without having to regenerate all wrappers, which is incredibly wasteful.

No idea why we didn't come up with this solution way before, it makes so much sense now :sweat_smile: (and rumors have it that there may be a simplified JLLWrappers as stdlib in Julia v1.7 :eyes:)

attachments.title: Using Alpine can make Python Docker builds 50× slower
attachments.text: When you’re choosing a base image for your Docker image, Alpine Linux is often recommended. Using Alpine, you’re told, will make your images smaller and speed up your builds. And if you’re using Go that’s reasonable advice. But if you’re using Python, Alpine Linux will quite often: Make your builds much slower. Make your images bigger. Waste your time. On occassion, introduce obscure runtime bugs. Let’s see why Alpine is recommended, and why you probably shouldn’t use it for your Python application.
